Eucational backgrouns: MBA, Duke University; Bachelor of Economics, Nankai University; Behavioral Interview certificate; Coaching Certificate, Satir Institute.
work_experience: 11 years senior management experience in Career Service at business school, HR recruiting, Strategy, Sales/Marketing. 20 years’ career coaching for students, professionals. International leadership roles in China, US, Canada. Various director/manager roles in top firms. Built and turned around teams, developed talent, managed budgets and strategy. Coached 5000+ international students.
Why are you considering career planning: Reviewing, reflecting on, or clarifying my own career journey and next steps
Can you share a story of an achievement: Promoted to Sales Director for Shanghai branch due to strong sales. Inherited underperforming team, low morale. Implemented reforms, raised morale, led team to achieve targets. Felt happy and empowered by the process.
What was the biggest challenge in this s: The biggest challenge was that the team lacked a good strategy, their capabilities couldn't keep up, and they lacked confidence. They were unsure how to develop new clients, felt the company brand wasn't strong, and had given up because they didn't believe they could be fired.
How did you overcome it?: I targeted these points: started by setting a strategy for them, then provided training, letting them see gradual improvement. At the same time, I adjusted the division of labor, redistributing resources more evenly, so everyone had some potential clients to start developing.
What key actions led to the outcome?: Set clear policies and structure, monitored progress and results, created a supportive environment focused on empowerment rather than micromanagement. Team became proactive and passionate.
Can you share another story from a diffe: Coached a recent graduate from ShanghaiTech University through a major/career pivot. Discovered his true interests/motivations, repositioned him for data analytics, helped match experience/resume, taught networking and interview skills, built confidence, and supported him to secure a full-time job after graduation.
Work experience: Worked as a financial advisor (banking) for ~5 years
Can you share a story of an achievement: Promoted to Sales Director to manage the Shanghai branch due to strong sales; implemented reforms, raised morale, and led team to achieve both individual and overall targets, resulting in happiness and a sense of potential.
What was the specific situation and the: Colleagues didn’t know how to develop new clients; company brand wasn’t strong; sales were difficult; most people gave up due to repeated failure and weak accountability. Biggest challenge: lack of good strategy, low capability, and low confidence. Responded by setting clear strategy, provided training, redistributed resources so everyone could develop potential clients.
What were your thought process and consi: Recognized that sales methods drive results, so applied my own successful strategies, organized them into practical steps, provided hands-on training, and focused on boosting the team’s confidence and motivation by helping them experience early success. My goal was to nurture self-driven individuals.
What key actions led to the outcome: Created and applied clear policy, monitored progress, reviewed results, stopped micro-management; empowered team to take responsibility for their own development, resulting in stronger capability and positivity.
How did you approach this differently th: Focused on root-cause diagnosis, structured strategies, confidence-building, and hands-on empowerment to drive lasting change. Emphasized both individual growth and system-level solutions.
Can you share another story from a diffe: Coached a graduate from ShanghaiTech University who lacked direction and confidence in his chosen major. Through deep exploration of his true inclinations, repositioned him for data analytics, helped clarify goals and develop necessary materials, provided confidence-building and interview guidance, and coached networking skills. Result: secured a full-time job in his area of interest after graduation.
What common strengths or patterns appear: Ability to diagnose issues at their core, craft tailored strategies, build confidence, and mobilize others’ intrinsic motivation—combining analytical and people-focused approaches for individual and systemic outcomes.
Which tasks or activities make you feel: Energized by solving complex, novel problems with visible results. Drained by routine, trivial, detail-heavy tasks with little creativity.
How do you prefer to learn and acquire n: Quickly grasp main concepts and underlying methods, minimize repetitive practice, learn by doing, and seek practical input from others to improve.
What motivates you most and gives you a: Making others better and receiving recognition from others. Also, accomplishing things others cannot do.
Which forms of recognition or achievemen: Recognition from others, public praise, seeing direct positive outcomes for others, and achieving hard or unique successes.
What childhood interests or early role-p: Ticket seller, selling things, imagined being a female spy and a diplomat—roles involving communication, persuasion, strategy, and problem solving.
How do others perceive your key strength: Brainstorming ideas, making decisions, initiating action—seen as strategic, decisive, creative, and proactive.
What considerations guided your decision: The sales method determines the outcome. Based on my past successful sales experience, I summarized a set of effective successful practices. I trained the team to master these, helping both individual and team performance to improve. By showing them hope and the ability to earn more commission, I encouraged them to strive to do better and become self-driven.
How did your approach differ from others: My approach was different in that I didn't just focus on short-term performance or reprimanding the team. Instead, I used a methodical, step-by-step approach—summarizing actionable best practices from my experience, providing specific training, fostering hope, and making them see the results. I encouraged self-motivation by helping them feel their efforts led to real rewards and progress, rather than pressuring or forcing them. This turned the group into self-driven individuals.
Can you share another story from a diffe: Shared a detailed story about guiding a ShanghaiTech graduate from uncertainty about his major/career to finding a suitable field (data analytics), helping him build confidence, identify suitable internships, polish his resume, and improve networking and interview skills.
